summary: Final year engineering project: Smart AI Footstep Electricity Generation using IoT. A web dashboard app that displays AI-driven energy management from footstep-powered generators. The dashboard should show blank/empty state until real hardware is connected and sending data. Features IoT sensor data display, AI smart energy routing, overcharge prevention, time-of-day pattern learning, and energy flow visualization. Includes an HTTP API endpoint for real hardware (Arduino/ESP32/Raspberry Pi) to send sensor data.
architectural_notes: AI logic rules implemented client-side: if battery > 90%, route power directly to devices; store energy during peak hours; draw from storage during low traffic
Dashboard displays blank/empty state by default — no simulated data. Data only appears when real hardware sends readings via HTTP POST to the backend API endpoint.

existing_features.title: Build a real-time IoT sensor data display panel on the frontend showing: current footstep count (steps/min), current voltage generated (W), battery level as a percentage with a visual progress bar, and current AI mode with a color-coded status badge (green = charging, amber = redirecting, blue = using stored).

Build an AI Smart Energy Management decision panel on the frontend that shows the current AI decision with explanation text (e.g., 'Battery is 95% full — redirecting power to lights and devices'), overcharge protection status indicator, and a log of recent AI decisions with timestamps.

Build an animated energy flow diagram on the frontend that visually shows the power path: Footsteps → Generator → Battery → Devices/Lights. Highlight the active path based on current AI mode (e.g., when battery is full, highlight the Battery → Devices path; when charging, highlight the Generator → Battery path).

Build analytics charts on the frontend showing: (1) hourly footstep count over the last 24 simulated hours as a bar chart, (2) energy generated (voltage) over time as a line chart, and (3) battery level trend over time as a line chart. Charts should update as new data arrives.

Apply a bold industrial/tech visual theme across the entire dashboard: dark background with neon accent colors (amber/green/cyan), large data readout typography, card-based layout with subtle glowing borders, and a header displaying the project title 'Smart AI Footstep Energy System'. The design should feel like a professional engineering control room dashboard.

Update the frontend dashboard to show a blank/empty waiting state on all panels (SensorDataPanel, AIDecisionPanel, EnergyFlowDiagram, AnalyticsCharts, SimulationControl) when the backend isHardwareConnected flag is false. Display a centered placeholder message such as 'Waiting for hardware connection...' with a subtle pulsing indicator. Once hardware connects and the flag becomes true, render all panels normally with live data. Poll the isHardwareConnected status every 3 seconds using React Query.

new_feature_requests.summary: Real-time IoT sensor data display (footstep count, voltage generated, battery level) with simulated data feed
AI smart energy management panel showing decisions: charging, redirecting to devices, or using stored energy
Overcharge prevention logic: AI stops charging when battery is full and reroutes power to devices
Time-of-day traffic pattern learning visualization (morning = high steps/power, afternoon = fewer steps)
Energy flow diagram showing path: Footsteps → Generator → Battery → Devices/Lights
Analytics charts: daily/hourly footstep count, energy generation over time, battery level trends

Create a backend actor that stores and manages simulated IoT sensor data including: footstep count per hour, voltage generated (in watts), battery level percentage (0–100%), current AI mode (charging / redirecting to devices / using stored energy), and timestamped historical records for analytics.

Implement AI energy management logic in the backend that: stops charging when battery level exceeds 90% (overcharge prevention), reroutes power directly to devices/lights when battery is full, draws from stored battery energy during low-traffic periods, and determines current mode based on footstep count and battery level.

Implement time-of-day traffic pattern simulation in the backend: morning hours (6am–12pm) produce high footstep counts (80–150 steps/min) and high voltage; afternoon hours (12pm–6pm) produce lower footstep counts (30–70 steps/min) and lower voltage; evening/night hours produce minimal activity. The simulation should auto-tick every few seconds to advance sensor readings.
Dashboard shows blank/empty state (no simulated data) until real hardware sends data via API. Once hardware connects and POSTs sensor readings, data appears live on the dashboard.
Add a backend HTTP API endpoint that accepts real sensor data (footstep count, voltage, battery level) from hardware devices (Arduino, ESP32, Raspberry Pi) via POST request.

Add a 'hardware connected' flag to the backend state. This flag starts as false. When real sensor data is received via the hardware POST API endpoint, set the flag to true. Expose a query function (e.g., isHardwareConnected) that returns this boolean so the frontend can check connection status.
